conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the given information to find the coefficient of friction \(\mu\) and the angle \(\theta\).
The image shows a suitcase which can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, with the ratio \(\mu\).
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is \(\theta\).

premise: Weight (W): The weight of the suitcase is \(W = mg = 15 \, \text{kg} \times 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 150 \, \text{N}\).
conclusion: The weight of the suitcase is 150 N.

premise: Normal Force (N): The normal force is the force exerted by the ground on the suitcase, perpendicular to the surface.
conclusion: The normal force is perpendicular to the ground.

premise: Applied Force (F): The force applied by the passenger is 90 N at an angle \(\theta\).
conclusion: The applied force is 90 N at an angle \(\theta\).

premise: Frictional Force (f): The frictional force is proportional to the normal force, \(f = \mu N\).
The applied force can be resolved into horizontal (\(F_x\)) and vertical (\(F_y\)) components: \(F_x = F \cos \theta\), \(F_y = F \sin \theta\).
conclusion: The horizontal component is \(F \cos \theta\) and the vertical component is \(F \sin \theta\).

premise: For the suitcase to move uniformly, the horizontal and vertical forces must be in equilibrium.
conclusion: The forces must be in equilibrium for uniform movement.
